content: I want to point out that "the uniqueness of such next number is guaranteed" is not true for the "very short" Test case. In fact, since the solution mathematically speaking is just a linear equation system with two variables, no sequence of length 2 can have a unique solution. -4 *5 solves the test case like an infinite other things

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Description is clear, and the idea behind is clever ! And the tests are diverse and well-defined.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice puzzle. I thought the series would be Un+1 = a*(Un + c) + b. I was able to solve the puzzle running with this error and I even was confused when I had 3 variables but only two equations on several of the test cases. Obviously, what I missed was covered in one of the author's earlier comments:

"every list of operators, as long as you want, can always be reduced to a list of 2 operators, with the same result"

I learned a nice lesson on this little puzzle.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Very nice puzzle based on series of the form Un+1 = a*Un + b. Great idea!
Is there a reason you do not have a test case where the crazy list has only 2 items that are not equal to each other?
Well It's clear and good, but I don't think that sould be a puzzle. It could be a clash, it is doable in less than 5 minutes.

Problem is interesting, but the statement is not complete:
1. No guides how Machinist handle end of the operations list. One should guess by the Examples.
2. I can't be sure is the operation list cycled already on the specific input or not yet. For sample input: `1 4 7 10` i can't be sure is operations list just `+3` or `+3 +3 +3 *100`. If the second, than the right answer should be 1000, but not 13.

Goal section
* Please change "iterations" to "iteration".

* In the second example, the operator -1 should actually be +(-1). Alternatively, please include "subtract" as one of the possible crazy operators.

Thanks.
Done.
I updated. Is it more clear ?

>> "it is doable in less than 5 minutes"

Does that mean you did it in less than 5 minutes or you "think" it is doable in 5 minutes?

This puzzle took me over an hour and a significant amount of algebra. It's very possible I am just missing the easy way to solve this problem, but right now, I'm not seeing it. Now that I've solved it, I guess I can go look at the author's solution, but your comment makes me think I'm missing something and I'd love to find the "trick" the old fashioned way.

You have U(n+1) = a * U(n) + b. You need 2 equations (that is 3 terms) to determine a and b ( for example u0, u1 and u2 ==> u1 = a u0 + b; u2 = a u1 + b). It is therefore unsolvable if have less than three items.
Any list having two consecutive values that are equal has a unique solution: a constant list.
My bad, you are implying uniqueness of the next number not uniqueness of the simplified operators, naturally.
Unless the 2 successive items are equal, in which case it's a constant series U(n) = U(0) = constant.
With 2 different values, all the values are a valid answer.

I think two constraints should be added:
(1) There are at least two integers in the given list.
(2) Each case is guaranteed to have a unique solution.

As discussed, it is impossible to solve cases such as 1 3 because there is more than one possible solutions.

I don't own this puzzle but I updated accordingly:
(1) I think there is no need to explicitely say that there is two or more elements in the list, as it is made by an initial value and calculated next values, so it has at least two values by definition.
(2) I added the uniqueness statement.
It seems obvious that the solution is unique, it's the case for all the codingame's problems.

Yes, but another option is to have cases where there is more than one mathematical solution (a list of 2 distinct integers) then the codingame solution is some message like "Infinite crazy lists here!"

Caduchon, that's not true. The puzzles which feature a viewer typically allow more than one solution.

And the point is not even about that. The point is you need to explicitly mention such a constraint to let the player know what the underlying assumptions when they write the code.

In most other puzzles, yes, the solution is unique, but in many cases that constraint does not affect how the solution is written. But for your puzzle, one would wonder how to deal with those cases with more than one solutions. So it's the author's responsibility to clarify that such cases won't appear.
"It seems obvious that the solution is unique," <- It seems obvious that there are many cases where the solution is NOT unique; it's just that they aren't included in this puzzle.
If the solution required solving with algebra that would make it not good for clash... but the test cases can be all be solved by brute force, checking each multiplier in range -99..99
For what it’s worth, necessary or not, the algebraic solution sure was fun!
Well as CarlWash said you can easily brute force it, I don't really remember how much time I took to do it the algebraic way, I didn't mesured it in fact, but probably about 6~8 minutes I think

1. ok
2. Still not ok. If we know nothing about the operators list, we can't predict anything.
The operators are always the same during the list creation.  I added this: "He repeats the operators application increasing the crazy list (the same operators with the same order)".

Again, I can't be sure is the list given me in the input was created using all of the operators, or not yet all?

I believe that if you add that operator list is always shorter than input list, than it would be ok.

The operators list can be larger than the input. But, the list of operators is always the same to generate each number from the previous one. 

Maybe you miss a mathematical aspect ? : every list of operators, as long as you want, can always be reduced to a list of 2 operators, with the same result.

Oh, now I got it!

It is unclear from the statements, that Machinist apply ALL of the operators to get only one next value.

"apply them on the last value of the crazy list to increase it" → "apply all of them on the last value of the crazy list to calculate next value" 

Also I think it is better to change "increase" to "grow" to remove confusion with the increasing the item of list.
Updated. Thanks for your help.
